<s> INTRODUCTION
 </s>

<s> With the title of _Sense and Sensibility_ is connected one of those minor
 </s>

<s> problems which delight the cummin-splitters of criticism. In the _Cecilia_
 </s>

<s> of Madame D'Arblay--the forerunner, if not the model, of Miss Austen--is a
 </s>

<s> sentence which at first sight suggests some relationship to the name of
 </s>

<s> the book which, in the present series, inaugurated Miss Austen's novels.
 </s>

<s> 'The whole of this unfortunate business'--says a certain didactic Dr.
 </s>

<s> Lyster, talking in capitals, towards the end of volume three of
 </s>

<s> _Cecilia_--'has been the result of PRIDE and PREJUDICE,' and looking to
 </s>

<s> the admitted familiarity of Miss Austen with Madame D'Arblay's work, it
 </s>

<s> has been concluded that Miss Austen borrowed from _Cecilia_, the title of
 </s>

<s> her second novel. But here comes in the little problem to which we have
 </s>

<s> referred. _Pride and Prejudice_ it is true, was written and finished
 </s>

<s> before _Sense and Sensibility_--its original title for several years being
 </s>

<s> _First Impressions_. Then, in 1797, the author fell to work upon an older
 </s>

<s> essay in letters _a la_ Richardson, called _Elinor and Marianne_, which
 </s>

<s> she re-christened _Sense and Sensibility._ This, as we know, was her first
 </s>

<s> published book; and whatever may be the connection between the title of
 </s>

<s> _Pride and Prejudice_ and the passage in _Cecilia_, there is an obvious
 </s>

<s> connection between the title of _Pride and Prejudice_ and the _title of
 </s>

<s> Sense and Sensibility_. If Miss Austen re-christened _Elinor and
 </s>

<s> Marianne_ before she changed the title of _First Impressions_, as she well
 </s>

<s> may have, it is extremely unlikely that the name of _Pride and Prejudice_
 </s>

<s> has anything to do with _Cecilia_ (which, besides, had been published at
 </s>

<s> least twenty years before). Upon the whole, therefore, it is most likely
 </s>

<s> that the passage in Madame D'Arblay is a mere coincidence; and that in
 </s>

<s> _Sense and Sensibility_, as well as in the novel that succeeded it in
 </s>

<s> publication, Miss Austen, after the fashion of the old morality plays,
 </s>

<s> simply substituted the leading characteristics of her principal personages
 </s>

<s> for their names. Indeed, in _Sense and Sensibility_ the sense of Elinor,
 </s>

<s> and the sensibility (or rather _sensiblerie_) of Marianne, are markedly
 </s>

<s> emphasised in the opening pages of the book But Miss Austen subsequently,
 </s>

<s> and, as we think, wisely, discarded in her remaining efforts the cheap
 </s>

<s> attraction of an alliterative title. _Emma_ and _Persuasion, Northanger
 </s>

<s> Abbey_ and _Mansfield Park_, are names far more in consonance with the
 </s>

<s> quiet tone of her easy and unobtrusive art.
 </s>

<s> _Elinor and Marianne_ was originally written about 1792. After the
 </s>

<s> completion--or partial completion, for it was again revised in
 </s>

<s> 1811--of _First Impressions_ (subsequently _Pride and Prejudice_),
 </s>

<s> Miss Austen set about recasting _Elinor and Marianne_, then composed
 </s>

<s> in the form of letters; and she had no sooner accomplished this task,
 </s>

<s> than she began _Northanger Abbey_. It would be interesting to know to
 </s>

<s> what extent she remodelled _Sense and Sensibility_ in 1797-98, for we
 </s>

<s> are told that previous to its publication in 1811 she again devoted a
 </s>

<s> considerable time to its preparation for the press, and it is clear
 </s>

<s> that this does not mean the correction of proofs alone, but also a
 </s>

<s> preliminary revision of MS. Especially would it be interesting if we
 </s>

<s> could ascertain whether any of its more finished passages, _e.g._ the
 </s>

<s> admirable conversation between the Miss Dashwoods and Willoughby in
 </s>

<s> chapter x., were the result of those fallow and apparently barren
 </s>

<s> years at Bath and Southampton, or whether they were already part of
 </s>

<s> the second version of 1797-98. But upon this matter the records are
 </s>

<s> mute. A careful examination of the correspondence published by Lord
 </s>

<s> Brabourne in 1884 only reveals two definite references to _Sense and
 </s>

<s> Sensibility_ and these are absolutely unfruitful in suggestion. In
 </s>

<s> April 1811 she speaks of having corrected two sheets of 'S and S,'
 </s>

<s> which she has scarcely a hope of getting out in the following June;
 </s>

<s> and in September, an extract from the diary of another member of the
 </s>

<s> family indirectly discloses the fact that the book had by that time
 </s>

<s> been published. This extract is a brief reference to a letter which
 </s>

<s> had been received from Cassandra Austen, begging her correspondent not
 </s>

<s> to mention that Aunt Jane wrote _Sense and Sensibility._ Beyond these
 </s>

<s> minute items of information, and the statement--already referred to in
 </s>

<s> the Introduction to _Pride and Prejudice_--that she considered herself
 </s>

<s> overpaid for the labour she had bestowed upon it, absolutely nothing
 </s>

<s> seems to have been preserved by her descendants respecting her first
 </s>

<s> printed effort. In the absence of particulars some of her critics have
 </s>

<s> fallen to speculate upon the reason which made her select it, and not
 </s>

<s> _Pride and Prejudice_, for her debut; and they have, perhaps
 </s>

<s> naturally, found in the fact a fresh confirmation of that traditional
 </s>

<s> blindness of authors to their own best work, which is one of the
 </s>

<s> commonplaces of literary history. But this is to premise that she
 </s>

<s> _did_ regard it as her masterpiece, a fact which, apart from this
 </s>

<s> accident of priority of issue, is, as far as we are aware, nowhere
 </s>

<s> asserted. A simpler solution is probably that, of the three novels she
 </s>

<s> had written or sketched by 1811, _Pride and Prejudice_ was languishing
 </s>

<s> under the stigma of having been refused by one bookseller without the
 </s>

<s> formality of inspection, while _Northanger Abbey_ was lying _perdu_ in
 </s>

<s> another bookseller's drawer at Bath. In these circumstances it is
 </s>

<s> intelligible that she should turn to _Sense and Sensibility_, when, at
 </s>

<s> length--upon the occasion of a visit to her brother in London in the
 </s>

<s> spring of 1811--Mr. T. Egerton of the 'Military Library,' Whitehall,
 </s>

<s> dawned upon the horizon as a practicable publisher.
 </s>

<s> By the time _Sense and Sensibility_ left the press, Miss Austen was
 </s>

<s> again domiciled at Chawton Cottage. For those accustomed to the
 </s>

<s> swarming reviews of our day, with their Babel of notices, it may seem
 </s>

<s> strange that there should be no record of the effect produced, seeing
 </s>

<s> that, as already stated, the book sold well enough to enable its
 </s>

<s> putter-forth to hand over to its author what Mr. Gargery, in _Great
 </s>

<s> Expectations_, would have described as 'a cool L150.' Surely Mr.
 </s>

<s> Egerton, who had visited Miss Austen at Sloane Street, must have later
 </s>

<s> conveyed to her some intelligence of the way in which her work had
 </s>

<s> been welcomed by the public. But if he did, it is no longer
 </s>

<s> discoverable. Mr. Austen Leigh, her first and best biographer, could
 </s>

<s> find no account either of the publication or of the author's feelings
 </s>

<s> thereupon. As far as it is possible to judge, the critical verdicts
 </s>

<s> she obtained were mainly derived from her own relatives and intimate
 </s>

<s> friends, and some of these latter--if one may trust a little anthology
 </s>

<s> which she herself collected, and from which Mr. Austen Leigh prints
 </s>

<s> extracts--must have been more often exasperating than sympathetic. The
 </s>

<s> long chorus of intelligent approval by which she was afterwards
 </s>

<s> greeted did not begin to be really audible before her death, and her
 </s>

<s> 'fit audience' during her lifetime must have been emphatically 'few,'
 </s>

<s> Of two criticisms which came out in the _Quarterly_ early in the
 </s>

<s> century, she could only have seen one, that of 1815; the other, by
 </s>

<s> Archbishop Whately, the first which treated her in earnest, did not
 </s>

<s> appear until she had been three years dead. Dr. Whately deals mainly
 </s>

<s> with _Mansfield Park_ and _Persuasion_; his predecessor professed to
 </s>

<s> review _Emma_, though he also gives brief summaries of _Sense and
 </s>

<s> Sensibility_ and _Pride and Prejudice_. Mr. Austen Leigh, we think,
 </s>

<s> speaks too contemptuously of this initial notice of 1815. If, at
 </s>

<s> certain points, it is half-hearted and inadequate, it is still fairly
 </s>

<s> accurate in its recognition of Miss Austen's supreme merit, as
 </s>

<s> contrasted with her contemporaries--to wit, her skill in investing the
 </s>

<s> fortunes of ordinary characters and the narrative of common
 </s>

<s> occurrences with all the sustained excitement of romance. The Reviewer
 </s>

<s> points out very justly that this kind of work, 'being deprived of all
 </s>

<s> that, according to Bayes, goes "to elevate and surprise," must make
 </s>

<s> amends by displaying depth of knowledge and dexterity of execution.'
 </s>

<s> And in these qualities, even with such living competitors of her own
 </s>

<s> sex as Miss Edgeworth and Miss Brunton (whose _Self-control_ came out
 </s>

<s> in the same year as _Sense and Sensibility_), he does not scruple to
 </s>

<s> declare that 'Miss Austen stands almost alone.' If he omits to lay
 </s>

<s> stress upon her judgment, her nice sense of fitness, her restraint,
 </s>

<s> her fine irony, and the delicacy of her artistic touch, something must
 </s>

<s> be allowed for the hesitations and reservations which invariably beset
 </s>

<s> the critical pioneer.
 </s>

<s> To contend, however, for a moment that the present volume is Miss
 </s>

<s> Austen's greatest, as it was her first published, novel, would be a
 </s>

<s> mere exercise in paradox. There are, who swear by _Persuasion_; there
 </s>

<s> are, who prefer _Emma_ and _Mansfield Park_; there is a large
 </s>

<s> contingent for _Pride and Prejudice_; and there is even a section
 </s>

<s> which advocates the pre-eminence of _Northanger Abbey_. But no one, as
 </s>

<s> far as we can remember, has ever put _Sense and Sensibility_ first,
 </s>

<s> nor can we believe that its author did so herself. And yet it is she
 </s>

<s> herself who has furnished the standard by which we judge it, and it is
 </s>

<s> by comparison with _Pride and Prejudice_, in which the leading
 </s>

<s> characters are also two sisters, that we assess and depress its merit.
 </s>

<s> The Elinor and Marianne of _Sense and Sensibility_ are only inferior
 </s>

<s> when they are contrasted with the Elizabeth and Jane of _Pride and
 </s>

<s> Prejudice_; and even then, it is probably because we personally like
 </s>

<s> the handsome and amiable Jane Bennet rather better than the obsolete
 </s>

<s> survival of the sentimental novel represented by Marianne Dashwood.
 </s>

<s> Darcy and Bingley again are much more 'likeable' (to use Lady
 </s>

<s> Queensberry's word) than the colourless Edward Ferrars and the
 </s>

<s> stiff-jointed Colonel Brandon. Yet it might not unfairly be contended
 </s>

<s> that there is more fidelity to what Mr. Thomas Hardy has termed
 </s>

<s> 'life's little ironies' in Miss Austen's disposal of the two Miss
 </s>

<s> Dashwoods than there is in her disposal of the heroines of _Pride and
 </s>

<s> Prejudice_. Every one does not get a Bingley, or a Darcy (with a
 </s>

<s> park); but a good many sensible girls like Elinor pair off contentedly
 </s>

<s> with poor creatures like Edward Ferrars, while not a few enthusiasts
 </s>

<s> like Marianne decline at last upon middle-aged colonels with flannel
 </s>

<s> waistcoats. George Eliot, we fancy, would have held that the fates of
 </s>

<s> Elinor and Marianne were more probable than the fortunes of Jane and
 </s>

<s> Eliza Bennet. That, of the remaining characters, there is certainly
 </s>

<s> none to rival Mr. Bennet, or Lady Catherine de Bourgh, or the
 </s>

<s> ineffable Mr. Collins, of _Pride and Prejudice_, is true; but we
 </s>

<s> confess to a kindness for vulgar matchmaking Mrs. Jennings with her
 </s>

<s> still-room 'parmaceti for an inward bruise' in the shape of a glass of
 </s>

<s> old Constantia; and for the diluted Squire Western, Sir John
 </s>

<s> Middleton, whose horror of being alone carries him to the point of
 </s>

<s> rejoicing in the acquisition of _two_ to the population of London.
 </s>

<s> Excellent again are Mr. Palmer and his wife; excellent, in their
 </s>

<s> sordid veracity, the self-seeking figures of the Miss Steeles. But the
 </s>

<s> pearls of the book must be allowed to be that egregious amateur in
 </s>

<s> toothpick-cases, Mr. Robert Ferrars (with his excursus in chapter
 </s>

<s> xxxvi. on life in a cottage), and the admirably-matched Mr. and Mrs.
 </s>

<s> John Dashwood. Miss Austen herself has never done anything better than
 </s>

<s> the inimitable and oft-quoted chapter wherein is debated between the
 </s>

<s> last-named pair the momentous matter of the amount to be devoted to
 </s>

<s> Mrs. Dashwood and her daughters; while the suggestion in chapters
 </s>

<s> xxxiii. and xxxiv. that the owner of Norland was once within some
 </s>

<s> thousands of having to sell out at a loss, deserves to be remembered
 </s>

<s> with that other memorable escape of Sir Roger de Coverley's ancestor,
 </s>

<s> who was only not killed in the civil wars because 'he was sent out of
 </s>

<s> the field upon a private message, the day before the battle of
 </s>

<s> Worcester.'
 </s>

<s> Of local colouring there is as little in _Sense and Sensibility_ as in
 </s>

<s> _Pride and Prejudice_. It is not unlikely that some memories of
 </s>

<s> Steventon may survive in Norland; and it may be noted that there is
 </s>

<s> actually a Barton Place to the north of Exeter, not far from Lord
 </s>

<s> Iddesleigh's well-known seat of Upton Pynes. It is scarcely possible,
 </s>

<s> also, not to believe that, in Mrs. Jennings's description of
 </s>

<s> Delaford--'a nice place, I can tell you; exactly what I call a nice
 </s>

<s> old-fashioned place, full of comforts and conveniences; quite shut in
 </s>

<s> with great garden walls that are covered with the best fruit-trees in
 </s>

<s> the country; and such a mulberry tree in one corner!'--Miss Austen had
 </s>

<s> in mind some real Hampshire or Devonshire country house. In any case,
 </s>

<s> it comes nearer a picture than what we usually get from her pen. 'Then
 </s>

<s> there is a dovecote, some delightful stew-ponds, and a very pretty
 </s>

<s> canal; and everything, in short, that one could wish for; and,
 </s>

<s> moreover, it is close to the church, and only a quarter of a mile
 </s>

<s> from the turnpike-road, so 'tis never dull, for if you only go and sit
 </s>

<s> up in an old yew arbour behind the house, you may see all the
 </s>

<s> carriages that pass along.' The last lines suggest those quaint
 </s>

<s> 'gazebos' and alcoves, which, in the coaching days, were so often to
 </s>

<s> be found perched at the roadside, where one might sit and watch the
 </s>

<s> Dover or Canterbury stage go whirling by. Of genteel accomplishments
 </s>

<s> there is a touch In the 'landscape in coloured silks' which Charlotte
 </s>

<s> Palmer had worked at school (chap, xxvi.); and of old remedies for the
 </s>

<s> lost art of swooning, in the 'lavender drops' of chapter xxix. The
 </s>

<s> mention of a dance as a 'little hop' in chapter ix. reads like a
 </s>

<s> premature instance of middle Victorian slang. But nothing is new--even
 </s>

<s> in a novel--and 'hop,' in this sense, is at least as old as _Joseph
 </s>

<s> Andrews_.
 </s>

<s> CHAPTER I
 </s>

<s> The family of Dashwood had long been settled in Sussex. Their estate
 </s>

<s> was large, and their residence was at Norland Park, in the centre of
 </s>

<s> their property, where, for many generations, they had lived in so
 </s>

<s> respectable a manner as to engage the general good opinion of their
 </s>

<s> surrounding acquaintance. The late owner of this estate was a single
 </s>

<s> man, who lived to a very advanced age, and who for many years of his
 </s>

<s> life, had a constant companion and housekeeper in his sister. But her
 </s>

<s> death, which happened ten years before his own, produced a great
 </s>

<s> alteration in his home; for to supply her loss, he invited and
 </s>

<s> received into his house the family of his nephew Mr. Henry Dashwood,
 </s>

<s> the legal inheritor of the Norland estate, and the person to whom he
 </s>

<s> intended to bequeath it. In the society of his nephew and niece, and
 </s>

<s> their children, the old Gentleman's days were comfortably spent. His
 </s>

<s> attachment to them all increased. The constant attention of Mr. and
 </s>

<s> Mrs. Henry Dashwood to his wishes, which proceeded not merely from
 </s>

<s> interest, but from goodness of heart, gave him every degree of solid
 </s>

<s> comfort which his age could receive; and the cheerfulness of the
 </s>

<s> children added a relish to his existence.
 </s>

<s> By a former marriage, Mr. Henry Dashwood had one son: by his present
 </s>

<s> lady, three daughters. The son, a steady respectable young man, was
 </s>

<s> amply provided for by the fortune of his mother, which had been large,
 </s>

<s> and half of which devolved on him on his coming of age. By his own
 </s>

<s> marriage, likewise, which happened soon afterwards, he added to his
 </s>

<s> wealth. To him therefore the succession to the Norland estate was not
 </s>

<s> so really important as to his sisters; for their fortune, independent
 </s>

<s> of what might arise to them from their father's inheriting that
 </s>

<s> property, could be but small. Their mother had nothing, and their
 </s>

<s> father only seven thousand pounds in his own disposal; for the
 </s>

<s> remaining moiety of his first wife's fortune was also secured to her
 </s>

<s> child, and he had only a life-interest in it.
 </s>

<s> The old gentleman died: his will was read, and like almost every
 </s>

<s> other will, gave as much disappointment as pleasure. He was neither so
 </s>

<s> unjust, nor so ungrateful, as to leave his estate from his nephew; but
 </s>

<s> he left it to him on such terms as destroyed half the value of the
 </s>

<s> bequest. Mr. Dashwood had wished for it more for the sake of his wife
 </s>

<s> and daughters than for himself or his son; but to his son, and his
 </s>

<s> son's son, a child of four years old, it was secured, in such a way,
 </s>

<s> as to leave to himself no power of providing for those who were most
 </s>

<s> dear to him, and who most needed a provision by any charge on the
 </s>

<s> estate, or by any sale of its valuable woods. The whole was tied up
 </s>

<s> for the benefit of this child, who, in occasional visits with his
 </s>

<s> father and mother at Norland, had so far gained on the affections of
 </s>

<s> his uncle, by such attractions as are by no means unusual in children
 </s>

<s> of two or three years old; an imperfect articulation, an earnest
 </s>

<s> desire of having his own way, many cunning tricks, and a great deal of
 </s>

<s> noise, as to outweigh all the value of all the attention which, for
 </s>

<s> years, he had received from his niece and her daughters. He meant not
 </s>
